article:
'Deontological ethics' or 'deontology' (from Greek deon, "obligation, duty"; and
[[-logy|-logia]]) is the normative ethical position that judges the morality of
an action based on the action's adherence to a rule or rules. [http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/ethics-
virtue/ "Ethics-virtue", Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy] It is
sometimes described as "duty" or "obligation" or "rule" -based ethics, because
rules "bind you to your duty". Waller, Bruce N.
2005. Consider Ethics: Theory, Readings, and Contemporary Issues. New York:
Pearson Longman: 23. Deontological ethics is commonly contrasted to
consequentialism. Flew, Antony. 1979. "Consequentialism". In A Dictionary of
Philosophy, (2nd Ed.). New York: St Martins: 73. Deontological ethics is
also contrasted to pragmatic ethics.
